posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
hi everybody,

there have been a few threads on here about speed and power limits, and of course there’s the new four -motor limit for drive.

has anyone considered mandating an energy -limiter, which could be a simple device with SB50 on both ends, that integrates the power during a match and just disconnects the battery after, say, 100 watt hours?  (or signals the rio to turn off the heartbeat or whatever)?

that would be a more interesting and accurate engineering constraint, I think, than trying to measure speed, or limit specific things like motors.

?

posts.name: Brendan Manning
posts.cooked: This sounds like a very good way to create feel bad moments. I don’t want to see a team go to start climbing, get barely off the ground and then lose their battery and fall back down. It also doesn’t necessarily cut down on collision speed as varying energy efficiency of other mechanisms will allow some teams to drive faster on average, or teams may be able to have bursts of faster speed balanced out by being slower at other times. If you’re already designing a device I would make it part of the main breaker and make it a stricter power limit because that’s much more correlated to how fast robots are able to move.

posts.name: Jake Potter
posts.cooked: I believe the PDP already reports total energy, and I’ve seen others mention competitions that use an energy limit, so it seems doable.  I can imagine a world where it works and also a world where a third of teams are just bewildered 2 minutes into every match.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 1554 Mentor, 694 Alum, LRI, FIRST Long Island RPC

posts.custom_user_title: 1554 Mentor, 694 Alum, LRI, FIRST Long Island RPC

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
yeah, both power and energy limits seem good.

in addition to the safety benefits, such a limiter would help avoid devoting student engineering attention to topics like battery grading, battery warmers, etc.  these are cool engineering topics, but maybe not what FIRST needs.

posts.name: UnofficialForth
posts.cooked:
Having been part of a competition that had speed limits and battery limits on things, it was incredibly degrading to teams that were rookies with little knowledge of how to get such a thing working. Each robot had a health total, and going over the limits hurt your robot. We ended up building the equivalent of a “why are you hitting yourself” drivetrain that couldn’t move. So we just had it sit there the entire match.

I’m sure there are ways to regulate overall current more so, but I’m still a proponent of other fixes, such as better bumpers (Kit’o’part bumpers anyone?)

Edit: Yes, there are other ways to limit than in code, we just need to be careful not to lower the floor.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
truher:

avoid devoting student engineering attention to topics like battery grading, battery warmers

Understanding / maximizing / effectively using your energy budget seems like a perfectly valid engineering topic to me (ask any EV manufacturer).

And we already have a limit – it’s somewhere between 9 and 18 Ah depending on how low you are willing to drive your battery voltage.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: yeah, it would be a cool engineering challenge if the students were able to actually work on it, but what I see is not the sort of analysis and design you’re suggesting, instead I see cargo cult thinking, folklore about the "good batteries’ etc.

posts.name: Ian Saam
posts.cooked:
Since E=mc^2, and the speed of light is constant…

It sounds like you’re asking for a lower weight limit

posts.name: Zach Hoegberg
posts.cooked:
I am by no means a physicist, so I may have parts of this wrong. Someone please correct me if you know better.

E=mc² is only true for bodies at rest. The full equation, necessary when a body is in motion, is actually E²=(mc²)²+(pc)² where p is the momentum of the body, i.e. mass times velocity. So simply putting an upper limit on the mass does nothing to limit the max energy without also putting an upper limit on velocity.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
Ninja_Bait:

I believe the PDP already reports total energy

Only the PDP , not the PDH . Although presumably if this were to become a rule it could be added with a firmware update.

declaration: package: edu.wpi.first.wpilibj, class: PowerDistribution

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
The Battery Beak is fine, but we find the West Mountain Radio CBA V Pro really helps us understand our batteries.

Regarding engineering challenges:  Here’s one of the recent questions we were asking ourselves: “should we just spin up the shooter the moment auton starts and leave it that way for all 15 seconds”.  Does that make our autons faster (yes), what does it do to our energy budget? So we charted the amps drawn at various shooter RPMs (which you can then divide by 240 to get Amp-hours).  Then compare those uses with an auton that is spinning up & spinning down the shooter over those 15 seconds. Next we can test what RPMs we need for our autons (do we need 5000, 4000, 3000, … RPMs to get the job done?  Then we can decide is this a net positive change.

posts.name: Joshua J
posts.cooked:
truher:

has anyone considered mandating an energy -limiter, which could be a simple device with SB50 on both ends, that integrates the power during a match and just disconnects the battery after, say, 100 watt hours? (or signals the rio to turn off the heartbeat or whatever)?

There are many fail states of robots that result in excess energy draw that don’t turn that energy draw into anything useful. If you’ve ever seen a tank drive with a bound up side, or a swerve drive drop a steering pinion, you know what I mean. Very high current draw and a drive that just looks slow and hobbled. Punishing teams when this happens via an early disable is not a good idea imo.

posts.name: Luke
posts.cooked:
I think that while the energy limits angle is interesting, it would probably discourage complex designs that feature lots of powered elements. In addition, it would make matches more about conserving power instead of going all out, which makes things less exciting for audiences, and could also affect climbs/other endgame performance because someone drove too fast early in the match. While robot speed does need to go down, I think there are better ways to do it without affecting everything else on the robot.

I think a much more likely chance that if FIRST implements more restrictions on motor power, it will be by changing the max breaker current from 40A to 30A. This could be for any motor controller, but I don’t think it would be hard to do it just for drive motors. Current being the limiting factor was working fine until motors started getting more powerful, so I think that simply lowering this limit to reflect the efficiency of modern motors is the best solution and will hopefully slow robots down.
